lesson.name: Lesson 7.6: Building Quadratic Functions to Describe Situations, Part 2

page.title: 7.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will build on your knowledge of using simple quadratic functions to describe how an object falls over time, given the effect of constantly changing speed. You will construct quadratic functions to represent projectile motions, objects that are launched directly upward. Working through the activities, you will discover that gravity affects the speed of a projectile, and the linear model will need to be represented differently to adjust for the change.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to: 

  • Create quadratic functions and graphs that represent a situation.
  • Relate the vertex of a graph and the zeros of a function to a situation.
  • Know that the domain of a function can depend on the situation it represents.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.6.1: Using Linear Functions to Describe Constant Speed
  • 7.6.2: The Force of Gravity Change in Quadratic Functions
    • 7.6.2: Self Check 
    • 7.6.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.6.3: Using Quadratic Functions to Describe Height
    • 7.6.3: Self Check 
    • 7.6.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.6.4: Interpreting Graphs of Quadratic Functions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.6.5: Practice
  • 7.6.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.6.1: Using Linear Functions to Describe Constant Speed
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

A cannon is 10 feet off the ground. It launches a cannonball straight up with a velocity of 406 feet per second.

Imagine that there is no gravity and that the cannonball continues to travel upward with the same velocity.

  1. Answer questions a–f using the table with the heights of the cannonball at different times.

Seconds

Distance above ground (feet)

0

10

1

a. _____

2

b. _____

3

c. _____

4

d. _____

5

e. _____

\(t\)

f. _____

    1. How far above the ground is the cannonball at 1 second?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The cannonball is 416 feet above the ground at 1 second.

The correct answer is: The cannonball is 416 feet above the ground at 1 second.

    1. How far above the ground is the cannonball at 2 seconds?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The cannonball is 822 feet above the ground at 2 seconds.

The correct answer is: The cannonball is 822 feet above the ground at 2 seconds.

    1. How far above the ground is the cannonball at 3 seconds?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The cannonball is 1,228 feet above the ground at 3 seconds.

The correct answer is: The cannonball is 1228 feet above the ground at 3 seconds.

    1. How far above the ground is the cannonball at 4 seconds?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The cannonball is 1634 feet above the ground at 4 seconds.

The correct answer is: The cannonball is 1634 feet above the ground at 4 seconds.

    1. How far above the ground is the cannonball at 5 seconds?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The cannonball is 2040 feet above the ground at 5 seconds.

The correct answer is: The cannonball is 2040 feet above the ground at 5 seconds.


    1. How far above the ground is the cannonball at \(t\) seconds?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The cannonball is \(10+406t\) feet above the ground at \(t\) seconds.


  1. Write an equation to model the distance in feet, \(d\), of the ball \(t\) seconds after it was fired from the cannon, if there was no gravity.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(d=10+406t\)

page.title: 7.6.2: The Force of Gravity Change in Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Earlier, in activity 7.6.1, you completed a table that represents the height of a cannonball, in feet, as a function of time, in seconds, if there was no gravity.

This table shows the actual heights of the ball at different times.

Seconds

0

1

2

3

4

5

Distance above ground (feet)

10

400

758

1084

1378

1640


  1. Compare the values in this table with those in the table you completed earlier. What are two similarities or differences that you notice?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

  • The actual height values are all less than the hypothetical ones (except the first, before the cannonball has been fired).
  • The difference between the distances after some number of seconds is not constant. For example, 1 second after firing, the distances in the two tables are 416 and 400, a difference of 16 feet. Two seconds after firing, the difference between the two values is 64 feet.


  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course.

  1. Plot the two sets of data you have on the same coordinate plane.

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:


  1. How are the two graphs alike? How are they different?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The dots (triangles) that form a straight line represent the hypothetical data that ignore gravity. The dots that form a curve represent the actual heights. They both start at the same place (0,10). The hypothetical data show the heights increasing at a constant rate, in a linear pattern, while the actual data show values growing more slowly each successive second.

  1. What is the starting position for both graphs?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The starting position for both graphs is 10.

The correct answer is 10. The starting position for both graphs is 10.

  1. What was the constant rate of change for the cannonball without gravity?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The constant rate of change for the cannonball without gravity was 406.

The correct answer is 406. The constant rate of change for the cannonball without gravity was 406.

The constant rate of change is also the initial velocity. Recall that the effect of gravity is represented by \(16t^2\). Gravity causes the bend in the curve for the second table and graph because it pulls the cannonball down toward the ground.


  1. With a partner, write an equation to model the actual distance \(d\), in feet, of the ball \(t\) seconds after it was fired from the cannon. Consider gravity and how the points changed on the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Notice that gravity caused the heights to decrease, so, the effect of gravity is to subtract \(16t^2\). An equation for the actual height of the cannonball is \(d=10+406t-16t^2\).

page.title: 7.6.2: Self Check
page.contents: An arrow is shot up into the air from 5 feet, at an initial velocity of 200 feet per second. Which equation can represent the height, \(h(t)\), for any time, \(t\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to subtract the effects of gravity. The answer is \(h(t)=5+220t-16t^2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to subtract the effects of gravity. The answer is \(h(t)=5+220t-16t^2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Subtract the effect of gravity from the starting point and constant rate
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 220 is the initial velocity, not the starting height. The answer is \(h(t)=5+220t-16t^2\).

page.title: 7.6.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
The Effect of Gravity on Motion

A firework is sent up in the air, at an initial velocity of 130 feet per second, from a height of 6 feet. Write an equation that represents the height, \(h(t)\), of the firework for any second, \(t\). Remember to consider the effect of gravity.

Step 1
Identify the initial velocity, \(v_0\).
130 ft per second

Step 2
Identify the starting height, \(h_0\).
6

Step 3
Write an equation of this form: \(h(t)=h_0+v_0t-16t^2\).
\(h(t)=6+130t-16t^2\)

Try It: The Effect of Gravity on Motion


Write an equation if a firework is shot from 2 feet off the ground at an initial velocity of 110 feet per second. Write an equation that represents the height, \(h(t)\), of the firework for any second, \(t\). Remember to consider the effect of gravity.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write the equation for the height of the firework:

Step 1
Identify the initial velocity, \(v_0\).
110 ft per second

Step 2
Identify the starting height, \(h_0\).
2

Step 3
Write an equation of this form: \(h(t)=h_0+v_0t-16t^2\).
\(h(t)=2+110t-16t^2\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.6.3: Using Quadratic Functions to Describe Height
page.contents:
Activity

  1. The function defined by \(d=50+312t-16t^2\) gives the height in feet of a cannonball \(t\) seconds after the ball leaves the cannon.

    1. What does the term 50 tell us about the cannonball?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The 50 tells us the cannonball is fired from 50 feet off of the ground.


    1. What does the term \(312t\) tell us about the cannonball?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(312t\) tells us that the initial upward velocity is 312 feet per second.


    1. What does \(-16t^2\) tell us about the cannonball?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(-16t^2\) represents the effect of gravity pulling the cannonball back to the ground.



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Graph the function. Adjust the graphing window to the following boundaries: \(0<x<25\) and \(0<y<2000\).

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:


  1. Observe the graph and:

    1. Describe the shape of the graph. What does it tell us about the movement of the cannonball?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The distance from the ground increases, reaches a peak, and then decreases, which makes sense in the situation. It also looks like the distance from the ground decreases in the same way that it increased on the way up. The graph tells us the cannonball went up in the air, and then fell back down to the ground.



The shape of the quadratic function is called a parabola. It has a “U” shape.


    1. Estimate the maximum height the ball reaches. When does this happen?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The cannonball gets up to a little over 1500 feet, maybe to 1600 feet, at around 10 seconds.


The peak of the parabola, where the maximum occurs, is also called the vertex of the graph.


    1. Estimate when the ball hits the ground.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The cannonball hits the ground a little bit before 20 seconds.


The zero of a function is where the function equals 0, or where it crosses the \(x\)-axis. In this case, there is only one zero where the cannonball hits the ground. The parabola does cross the \(x\)-axis in the negative \(x\)-values, but that does not make sense in this problem.


  1. What domain is appropriate for this function? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The equation is a good model for the height of the cannonball from the time it is launched, \(t=0\), until the time it lands, just before \(t=20\). For times outside of these values, the function values do not mean anything in the context (for example, for \(t=21\) the function would place the cannonball underground).



Extending Your Thinking

If the cannonball were fired at 800 feet per second, would it reach a mile in height? Remember there are 5280 feet in a mile. Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The equation here would be \(g(t)=50+800t-16t^2\). Since \(g(10)=6450\) and there are 5280 feet in a mile, this cannonball would reach over a mile in height. This could also be seen by graphing the function.


Video: Using Quadratic Functions to Describe Height

Watch the following video to learn more about quadratic functions.

page.title: 7.6.3: Self Check
page.contents: A toy rocket is launched from a platform 4 feet above the ground at a velocity of 128 feet per second. Its height is graphed below. Approximately what is the rocket’s maximum height?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the time when the rocket hits the ground. The answer is 260 feet.
That’s correct! Check yourself: The peak, or vertex, of the graph is at approximately 260 feet.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the height at 1 second. The answer is 260 feet.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the velocity. The answer is 260 feet.

page.title: 7.6.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Reading Graphs of Quadratics

An object is thrown upward from a height of 5 feet with a velocity of 60 feet per second. Its height, \(h(t)\), in feet after \(t\) seconds is modeled by the function \(h(t)=5+60t-16t^2\).

Step 1
Identify the starting height.
5 feet

Step 2
Identify the maximum height by looking at the vertex or peak of the parabola.
approximately 62 feet

Step 3
Identify when the object reaches its maximum by matching the maximum with its matching time from the \(x\)-axis.
approximately 1.75 seconds

Step 4
When does the object hit the ground? 
Look at where the object has a height of 0 feet, or the zero of the function. This happens at approximately 3.75 seconds. Notice there would be another zero on the graph of the function to the left of \(x=0\), but that does not make sense in the problem because the object was thrown from 5 feet.

Try It: Reading Graphs of Quadratics

A rock is launched into the air, and its height is represented by the graph below.


What is the maximum height of the rock?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the maximum height:

Look at the peak, or vertex of the parabola.

The maximum height is 25 feet after 2 seconds.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.6.4: Interpreting Graphs of Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The height in feet, \(h\), of a stomp rocket (propelled by a short blast of air) above the ground after \(t\) seconds is given by the equation \(h(t)=5+100t-16t^2\). Here is a graph that represents \(h\).


  1. How does the 5 in the equation relate to the graph?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The graph intersects the vertical axis at 5.


  1. What does \(100t\) in the equation mean in terms of the rocket?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It indicates that the initial velocity of the rocket was 100 feet per second upward.


  1. What does the \(-16t^2\) mean in terms of the rocket?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This indicates the effect of gravity pulling the rocket back toward Earth.


  1. About when does the rocket hit the ground?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

At about 6.3 seconds.

page.title: 7.6.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The height of a diver above the water is given by \(h(t)=-5t2+10t+3, where \(t\) is time measured in seconds and \(h(t)\) is measured in meters. Select two statements that are true about the situation.

Correct! The diver begins 3 meters above the water. The function has 1 zero that makes sense in this situation.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The diver begins 3 meters above the water. The function has 1 zero that makes sense in this situation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The height of a baseball, in feet, is modeled by the function \(h\) given by the equation \(h(t)=3+60t-16t^2\). The graph of the function is shown.

    1. About when does the baseball reach its maximum height? Round to the nearest second.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The baseball reaches its maximum height just before 2 seconds.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The baseball reaches its maximum height just before 2 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. About how high is the maximum height of the baseball? Round to the nearest ten.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The maximum height of the baseball is about 60 feet.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The maximum height of the baseball is about 60 feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. When does the baseball hit the ground? Round to the nearest second.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The baseball hits the ground less than 4 seconds after the baseball was hit or thrown.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The baseball hits the ground less than 4 seconds after the baseball was hit or thrown. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Two rocks are launched straight up in the air. The height of Rock A is given by the function \(f\), where \(f(t)=4+30t-16ta^2\). The height of Rock B is given by \(g\), where \(g(t)=5+20t-16t^2\). In both functions, \(t\) is time measured in seconds and height is measured in feet.

The following is a graph of the functions. Use the graph to answer the questions a–c.

    1. Which graph is the height of Rock A, \(f(t)=4+30t-16t^2\)?

Correct! The red graph represents Rock A.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.6.2 and 7.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The red graph represents Rock A. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which graph is the he height of Rock B, \(g(t)=5+20t-16t^2\)?

Correct! The green graph represents Rock B.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.6.2 and 7.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The green graph represents Rock B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Determine which rock hits the ground first.

Correct! Rock B hits the ground first. The graph for Rock B (\(g(t)=5+20t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)-axis at about 1.5, which means it hits the ground about 1.5 seconds after launch. The graph for Rock A (\(f(t)=4+30t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)-axis at about 2, which means it hits the ground about 2 seconds after launch.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.6.2–7.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Rock B hits the ground first. The graph for Rock B \((g(t)=5+20t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)-axis at about 1.5, which means it hits the ground about 1.5 seconds after launch. The graph for Rock A \((f(t)=4+30t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)axis at about 2, which means it hits the ground about 2 seconds after launch. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Each expression represents an object’s distance from the ground, in meters, as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds.

Object A: \(-5t^2+25t+50\)

Object B: \(-5t^2+50t+25\)

  1. Which object was launched with the greater vertical speed?

Correct! Object B was launched with the greater vertical speed.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.6.2–7.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Object B was launched with the greater vertical speed. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which object was launched from the greater height?

Correct! Object A was launched from the greater height.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.6.2–7.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Object A was launched from the greater height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.6.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Create quadratic functions and graphs that represent a situation.
  • Relate the vertex of a graph and the zeros of a function to a situation.
  • Know that the domain of a function can depend on the situation it represents.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.6.1: Using Linear Functions to Describe Constant Speed
    • In this activity, you considered what happens if an object is launched up in the air unaffected by gravity. It reinforced your knowledge that an object that travels at a constant speed can be described with a linear function.
  • 7.6.2: The Force of Gravity Change in Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you learned a model that accounts for the fact that an object that is launched straight up at a constant speed does not keep going at the same rate when the influence of gravity is taken into account. The big lesson was that adding a quadratic term to a linear function has an effect of “bending” the graph, as the output values are no longer changing at a constant rate.
    • 7.6.2: Self Check
    • 7.6.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.6.3: Using Quadratic Functions to Describe Height
    • In this activity, you explored another model of a projectile motion. You graphed and interpreted a quadratic function in context and began considering a reasonable domain for the function.
    • 7.6.3: Self Check
    • 7.6.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.6.4: Interpreting Graphs of Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you examined a quadratic function and its graph and identified what each term of the equation meant in the context of the situation graphed.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.6.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
